<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	G &#150; estimated long-term growth rate from &#147;Damodaran Online&#148; at http://pages.stern.nyu.edu/~adamodar/
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	WACC &#150; Weighted Average Cost of Capital
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Sales CAGR &#150;
	Sales Compound Annual Growth Rate
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The fair value analysis of each long-lived asset not in use/to be disposed of is determined by means of
	third party independent appraisal. No impairment loss was recorded in 2015, while an impairment loss of &#128;0.4&nbsp;million and &#128;0.4&nbsp;million was recognized in 2014 and 2013 respectively.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The compound annual growth rate for sales for Italian production sites is based on the five- year business plan.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	37
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage42"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D190845D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The deterioration of the macroeconomic environment, retail industry and the deterioration of our
	performance, could affect our Italian production long lived assets. In performing the impairment analysis management has performed a sensitivity analysis, which results in an undiscounted cash flow exceeding the carrying amount of long lived assets
	with an adequate cushion.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	During 2015, as a result of the positive results achieved during the year, the Company did not perform an
	impairment review of its retail fixed assets. During 2014 the Company recorded an impairment loss of &#128;0.7&nbsp;million for the assets related to retail stores in the UK. During 2013 the Company performed an impairment review of its retail fixed
	assets: an impairment loss of &#128;0.7&nbsp;million was recorded for the assets related to retail stores in Italy, an impairment loss of &#128;0.6&nbsp;million was recorded for the assets related to retail stores in Spain and an impairment loss of
	&#128;0.8&nbsp;million was recorded for the German retail assets. Also, in 2013 the company recorded an impairment loss of &#128;6.0&nbsp;million for a specific asset (airplane) and &#128;0.4&nbsp;million for plants not in use/to be disposed of.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	For a discussion of the differences between Italian GAAP and U.S. GAAP with respect to the above impairment analysis and the effect on
	net loss and shareholders&#146; equity as of December&nbsp;31, 2015, please see Note 31(g) of the Consolidated Financial Statements included in item 18 of this Annual Report.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Goodwill and intangible assets &#151;
</B>
	Management tests goodwill and intangible assets for impairment by reporting unit at least once a
	year or whenever the events or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying amount of goodwill and intangible assets may be not recoverable.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company analyzes its overall valuation and performed the impairment analysis of its goodwill and intangible assets in accordance with
	Italian and U.S. GAAP. Under Italian GAAP the Company amortizes the goodwill and intangible assets arising from business acquisition on a straight-line basis over a period of five years.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Under U.S. GAAP goodwill and intangible assets are not amortized but annually tested for impairment. At December&nbsp;31, 2015, 2014 and 2013,
	the Company did not record any impairment loss for its goodwill and intangible assets (see notes 12 and 31(d) of the Consolidated Financial Statements included in Item&nbsp;18 of this Annual Report).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	For a discussion of the differences between Italian GAAP and U.S. GAAP with respect to the above impairment analysis and the effect on net
	loss and shareholders&#146; equity as of December&nbsp;31, 2015, please see Note 31(d) of the Consolidated Financial Statements included in Item&nbsp;18 of this Annual Report.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Although management believes its estimates in relation to such impairments are reasonable, actual results may differ, and future downward
	revisions to management&#146;s estimates, if any, may result in further charges in future periods.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Recoverability of Deferred Tax
	Assets &#151;
</B>
	Deferred tax assets and liabilities are recognized for the future tax consequences attributable to differences between the accounting in the consolidated financial statements of existing assets and liabilities and their respective
	tax bases, as well as for losses available for carrying forward in the various tax jurisdictions. Deferred tax assets are reduced by a valuation allowance to an amount that is reasonably certain to be realized. Deferred tax assets and liabilities
	are calculated using enacted tax rates expected to apply to taxable income in the years in which those temporary differences are expected to be recovered or settled. The effect on deferred tax assets and liabilities of a change in tax rates is
	recognized in the period that includes the enactment date.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In assessing the feasibility of the realization of deferred tax assets,
	management considers whether it is reasonably certain that some portion or all of the deferred tax assets will not be realized. The ultimate realization of deferred tax assets is dependent upon the generation of future taxable income during the
	periods in which those temporary differences become deductible and the tax loss carry forwards are utilized. Estimating future taxable income requires estimates about matters that are inherently uncertain and requires significant management
	judgment, and different estimates can have a significant impact on the outcome of the analysis.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In 2014 and 2015, because most of the
	Italian and foreign subsidiaries realized significant pre-tax losses and were in a cumulative loss position, management did not consider it reasonably certain that the deferred tax assets of those companies would be realized in the scheduled
	reversal periods (see Note 18 to the Consolidated Financial Statements included in Item&nbsp;18 of this Annual Report). In making its determination that a valuation allowance was required, management considered the scheduled reversal of deferred tax
	liabilities and tax planning strategies but was unable to identify any relevant tax planning strategies available to reduce the need for a valuation allowance.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	38
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage43"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D190845D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Changes in the assumptions and estimates related to future taxable income, tax planning
	strategies and scheduled reversal of deferred tax liabilities could affect the recoverability of the deferred tax assets. If actual results differ from such estimates and assumptions the Group financial position and results of operation may be
	affected.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	One-Time Termination Benefits &#151;
</B>
	In September 2011, the Company renewed its agreement with the Italian trade unions
	and the Ministry of Labor and Social Policy that permitted it to participate in a temporary workforce reduction program and to benefit from the &#147;
<I>
	Cassa Integrazione Guadagni Straordinaria
</I>
	,&#148; or CIGS, for a period of 24 months
	beginning on October&nbsp;16, 2011. Pursuant to the CIGS, government funds pay a substantial majority of the salaries of redundant workers who are subject to layoffs or reduced work schedules. For the 2011-2013 period, an average of 1,273 employees
	from the Group&#146;s headquarters and production facilities were covered by the program, which contemplated a surplus of 1,060 employees at the end of the period on October&nbsp;15, 2013.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Pursuant to this agreement, as of December&nbsp;31, 2011, the Company, accrued a one-time termination benefits reserve with an accrual of
	&#128;5.4&nbsp;million (for the 1,060 employees to be dismissed) recorded as a non-operating expense, under the line &#147;Other Income/(Expense), Net&#148; of the consolidated statement of operations for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2011, of
	which &#128;1.4&nbsp;million has been paid.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On October&nbsp;10, 2013, shortly before the expiration of the 2011 agreement, the Company
	entered into the 2013 Italian Reorganization Agreement with local institutions, Italian trade unions, the Ministries of Economic Development and of Labor and Social Policy and the regions of Puglia and Basilicata governing the reorganization plan
	for the Group&#146;s Italian operations. The plan contemplated by the 2013 Italian Reorganization Agreement anticipated future layoffs of 1,506 employees (instead of the 1,060 contemplated by the agreement signed in 2011). Due to the complexity of
	the measures envisioned by the plan and in order to better manage workforce reductions, the Company and the trade unions obtained a one-year extension of the Company&#146;s participation in the CIGS program through October&nbsp;15, 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company anticipated making incentive payments to induce the voluntary resignation of up to 600 employees at the conclusion of the period
	covered by the CIGS program. As a result, in 2013, the Company increased the one-time termination benefits reserve (reflecting both voluntary payments and those that must be made under Italian law in the event of employee terminations) with an
	accrual of &#128;19.9&nbsp;million, which was recorded as a non-operating expense, under the line &#147;Other Income/(Expense), Net.&#148;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	During 2014, the Company granted incentive payments to 429 workers, for an amount of &#128;13.5&nbsp;million, further to the individual
	agreements reached during the year. Also, the Company obtained a further one-year extension of its participation in the CIGs program (expiring on October&nbsp;16, 2015) for 1,550 workers. In the meantime, negotiations started with social parties to
	obtain a solidarity agreement aimed to avoid layoffs by reducing the number of daily work hours for all employees, and reduce the labor and social contribution costs. The 2015 Italian Reorganization Agreement was finally signed on March&nbsp;3, 2015
	and refers to a total of 1,818 workers. In 2014, remaining redundant workers amounted to 516. Based on the estimation of the number of redundancies, no accrual was posted in 2014 to the one-termination benefit reserve, since the remaining provision
	was deemed sufficient enough to cover the cost of future layoffs.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	During 2015, the Company granted incentive payments to 78 workers, for
	a total amount of &#128;4.5 million. In addition, 100 workers, who were originally employed at the Ginosa plant, were re-employed at the Jesce, Matera, and Laterza plants. As for the remaining redundancy, on July&nbsp;28, 2015, a new incentive
	payment program was launched, with an ultimate deadline of June&nbsp;30, 2016. As of December&nbsp;31, 2015, 65 workers participated in the new incentive payment program. As a result of these programs, the estimated remaining redundancy is 359
	workers. Based on this new estimate of the number of redundancies, an accrual of &#128;3.4&nbsp;million was posted in 2015 to the one-termination benefit reserve. Therefore, the remaining provision of &#128;10.2&nbsp;million at 2015 year-end has
	been deemed as sufficient to cover the cost of future layoffs.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	39
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage44"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D190845D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In accordance with Italian GAAP, the costs connected to one-time termination benefits were
	recognized in 2011, 2013 and 2015 due to the fact that in those years the Company formally decided to adopt the termination plans (which were approved by the Company&#146;s board of directors) and was able to reasonably estimate the related one-time
	termination benefits. Under Italian GAAP, the communication or announcement to third parties of the plan of termination of workers is not relevant to the recognition of the cost for the termination benefits related to the terminated workers.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Although management believes its estimates of the one-time termination benefits are reasonable, different assumptions regarding the number of
	employees to be laid off, the outcome of the negotiations with the trade unions and the relevant Italian Ministries, and other factors, could lead to different conclusions, which could have a significant impact on the figures determined.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Under U.S. GAAP, considering the guidance of ASC 420, the one-time termination benefits have to be recorded in the consolidated statement of
	operations when the termination plan is communicated to the employees and meets all the criteria indicated in paragraph 420-10-25-4. The effects of this different accounting treatment are indicated in Note 31(f) of the Consolidated Financial
	Statements included in Item&nbsp;18 of this Annual Report.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Allowances for Returns and Discounts &#151;
</B>
	The Group records revenues
	net of returns and discounts. The Group estimates sales returns and discounts and creates an allowance for them in the year of the related sales. The Group makes estimates in connection with such allowances based on its experience and historical
	trends in its large volumes of homogeneous transactions. However, actual costs for returns and discounts may differ significantly from these estimates if factors such as economic conditions, customer preferences or changes in product quality differ
	from the ones used by the Group in making these estimates.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Allowance for Doubtful Accounts &#151;
</B>
	The Group makes estimates and
	judgments in relation to the collectability of its accounts receivable and maintains an allowance for doubtful accounts based on losses it may experience as a result of failure by its customers to pay amounts owed. The Group estimates these losses
	using consistent methods that take into consideration, in particular, insurance coverage in place, the creditworthiness of its customers and general economic conditions. Changes to assumptions relating to these estimates could affect actual results.
	Actual results may differ significantly from the Group&#146;s estimates if factors such as general economic conditions and the creditworthiness of its customers are different from the Group&#146;s assumptions.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Revenue Recognition &#151;
</B>
	Under Italian GAAP, the Group recognizes sales revenue, and accrues associated costs, at the time products
	are shipped from its manufacturing facilities located in Italy and abroad. A significant part of the products are shipped from factories directly to customers under sales terms such that ownership, and thus risk, is transferred to the customer when
	the customer takes possession of the goods. These sales terms are referred to as &#147;delivered duty paid,&#148; &#147;delivered duty unpaid,&#148; &#147;delivered ex quay&#148; and &#147;delivered at customer factory.&#148; Delivery to the
	customer generally occurs within one to six weeks from the time of shipment. The Group&#146;s revenue recognition under Italian GAAP is at variance with U.S. GAAP. For a discussion of revenue recognition under U.S. GAAP, see Note 31(c) to the
	Consolidated Financial Statements included in Item&nbsp;18 of this Annual Report.
</P>
<EFX_RESULTS_OF_OPERATIONS>
<A NAME="FIS_RESULTS_OF_OPERATIONS"></A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:24PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
<B>
<A NAME="D190845D20F_HTM_TOC190845_30">
</A>
	Results of Operations
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Summary
</B>
	&#151; During 2015, the Company continued to dedicate significant efforts and resources to reorganizing its
	operations, and optimizing and streamlining processes to reduce costs and recover efficiency.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	While most of the activities included in
	the Business Plan (namely, new brand and distribution strategy; product innovation; the controlling and reduction of fixed costs; rationalization of the Directly Operated Stores network; new commercial organization) have been carried out, as of the
	date of this Annual Report, substantially in line with the scheduled timing, the implementation of the industrial process innovation project included in the Business Plan generated, during the first part of 2014, some unexpected difficulties,
	highlighting, therefore, the need for certain corrective measures within the Group&#146;s industrial operations, which resulted in a slower implementation of the Plan than originally envisaged.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	40
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage45"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D190845D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The corrective measures introduced in the second half of 2014 had a means to recover efficiency
	in our industrial plants allowed, indeed, the Group to gradually improve quarterly industrial margins during 2014, but not in a sufficient measure to return to profitability.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In 2015, thanks to the corrective measures introduced in the second half of 2014, the Group achieved positive results in terms of production
	efficiency (in particular for Italian and Chinese plant) and in terms of control and reduction of fixed costs and rationalization of the Directly Operated Stores network. As a consequence in 2015 EBIT improved from -&#128;37,0&nbsp;million in 2014
	to -&#128;7,6&nbsp;million in 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On the basis of the actions described above, during the second part of 2015, Natuzzi management
	prepared the 2016 budget, which was approved by the Board of Directors on November&nbsp;27, 2015. The budget foresees a further improvement in the Group&#146;s results, reaching positive operating results by the end of 2016. These results will be
	achieved mainly because of the positive contribution resulting from measures to improve efficiency, which were implemented during the last year.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In 2015, the Group had net losses of &#128;16.5&nbsp;million (compared to a net loss of &#128;49.4&nbsp;million in 2014). Group net sales
	increased by 5.9%, from &#128;461.4&nbsp;million in 2014 to &#128;488.5&nbsp;million in 2015. Total upholstery net sales increased by 6.8% to &#128;437.0&nbsp;million due to a positive exchange rate fluctuations, a generalized increase in the price
	list and a positive contribution from sales-mix. Such positive factors were partially offset by a decrease in terms of seats sold from 1,662,295 in 2014 to 1,543,259 in 2015. &#147;Other sales&#148; item, relates to the sales of furnishings,
	polyurethane and other minor revenues, decrease by 1.5% from &#128;52.3&nbsp;million in 2014 to &#128;51.5&nbsp;million in 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In 2015,
	net sales of the &#147;Natuzzi&#148; branded products (which include the Group&#146;s two lines of product:
<I>
	Natuzzi Italia and Natuzzi Editions
</I>
	)
<I>
	increased by 6.1%, from &#128;287.0&nbsp;million in 2014 to &#128;304.6&nbsp;million in 2015,
	with the number of seats sold decreasing by 6.6% to 851,368 as compared to 2014.
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Net sales of private label products (including
<I>
	Softaly
</I>
	) increased by 8.4% to &#128;132.4&nbsp;million, with the number of seats sold decreasing by 7.9% to 691,890. See &#147;Item 4. Information on the Company&#151;Markets&#148; for tables setting forth the Group&#146;s net leather- and
	fabric-upholstered furniture sales and seats sold, which are broken down by geographic market, for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2013, 2014 and 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Group, during 2015, carried on with the innovation and cost controlling program as envisaged by the Group&#146;s Transformation Plan,
	despite encountering delays in the original schedule, as previously described:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	i.
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	the re-engineering of our best-selling models into a moving-line based design, was completed by the end of 2014: starting from the end of March 2016, 80% of the Group&#146;s products can be manufactured through moving
	lines;
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	ii.
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	a significant reduction in the number of models and number of coverings, contributing to a reduction in the overall industrial complexity;
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	iii.
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	as for innovations in industrial processes, we have developed and tested in our experimental plant located in Matera a new integrated production cycle and production planning software. Results achieved in the year 2015
	are very encouraging in terms of improved efficiency, reduction of workers not directly involved in production and a new labour organization;
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	iv.
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	the closure of underperforming stores (23 from January 2013 through the date of this Annual Report), with three more Directly Operated Stores planned for closure during the course of 2016 (11 Stores closed during 2015);
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	v.
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	the creation of a centralized structure to oversee certain back-office activities and to right-size our trading subsidiaries abroad so to reduce costs;
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	vi.
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	a reduction in the managerial structure, particular in our headquarters.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In 2015 sales
	activity was characterized by a positive development in late spring, as a result of the overall review of our product collections and their presentations in the main world fairs (Milan, Guangzhou, High Point).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	From a geographical standpoint, North American market showed positive sales growth +6% and European sales increased 4.9%. A very impressive
	growth, +16%, was reached in Asia Pacific.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	41
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage46"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D190845D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In 2016 we expect the improving trend in our industrial operations that has started during the
	second part of 2014 and has given encouraging results in 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Specifically, the Group will continue to invest in product and process
	innovations according to &#147;Lean Production&#148; principles. In addition, we have nearly finished the review of our commercial organization in an effort to more effectively respond to market demands, with particular attention on fast-growing
	markets. The Company will also continue to further implement cost-saving measures aimed at lowering overhead costs and to develop our business relations with important customers by leveraging our capability in offering quality service and
	competitive products.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The following table sets forth certain statement of operations data expressed as a percentage of net sales for the
	years indicated:
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:24PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
<B>
<A NAME="D190845D20F_HTM_TOC190845_31">
</A>
	2015 Compared to 2014
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Total net sales
</B>
	for 2015, including sales of leather and fabric-upholstered furniture and other sales (principally sales of
	polyurethane foam and leather sold to third parties as well as of accessories), increased 5.9% to &#128;488.5&nbsp;million in 2015 as compared to &#128;461.4&nbsp;million in 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Net sales for 2015 of leather and fabric-upholstered furniture increased 6,8% to &#128;437.0&nbsp;million, as compared to
	&#128;409.1&nbsp;million in 2014. The 6,8% increase was due principally to a generalized price-list increase, a positive sales mix contribution and a positive currency translation, partially offset by a decrease in terms of seats sold from 1,662,295
	in 2014 to 1,543,259 in 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Net sales of Natuzzi branded products (which include sales of the Group&#146;s three lines of product:
<I>
	Natuzzi Italia
</I>
	,
<I>
	Natuzzi Editions
</I>
	and
<I>
	Natuzzi Re-Vive
</I>
	) accounted for 69.7% of our total upholstery net sales in 2015 (as compared to 70,1% in 2014); net sales of the private label production accounted for 29.9% of our total
	upholstery net sales in 2014 (as compared to 27.3% in 2013).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Net sales for 2015 of leather-upholstered furniture increased 6.9% to
	&#128;403.8&nbsp;million, as compared to &#128;374.4&nbsp;million in 2014, and net sales for 2015 of fabric-upholstered furniture increased 5.9% to &#128;36.7&nbsp;million, as compared to &#128;34.7&nbsp;million in 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	According to a geographic breakdown in total upholstery net sales, in the Americas (Brazil included), 2015 net sales increased by 6.0% to
	&#128;181.3&nbsp;million, as compared to &#128;171.0&nbsp;million in 2014, and seats sold decreased by 14.5% to 719.959, reflecting in particular the 20.8% decrease for our medium-low segment Private label net seats sold.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In EMEA, net sales of upholstered furniture in 2015 increased by 4.9% to &#128;193.9&nbsp;million, as compared to &#128;184.8&nbsp;million in
	2014, due to a 2.4% decrease in Natuzzi branded offerings, and a 29.3% increase in sales of our Private Label offerings, leveraging on new key accounts. Seats sold in the region in 2015 increased by 3,8% to 668,891 units, primarily due to private
	label increase that more than offset Natuzzi brand decrease in seat sold.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In the Asia-Pacific region, net sales of upholstered furniture
	increased by 16,0% to, &#128;61.9&nbsp;million as compared to &#128;53.3&nbsp;million in 2014. Seats sold decreased by 11.9% in that region to 154,409.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	42
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage47"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D190845D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Upholstered furniture seats sold in 2015 decreased in all regions (except for Private Label in
	EMEA where seats sold increased 19% compared to 2014). Nonetheless, the Group realized a better product mix for each product line, even if we make a comparison at constant exchange rate and without considering the 2015 generalized price increase.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	According to a breakdown by brand, net sales for 2015 of the Natuzzi branded furniture increased by 6.1% over 2014 to
	&#128;304.6&nbsp;million, and the number of seats sold decreased by 6.6% to 851.368. Net sales of private label products in 2015 increased by 8.4% over 2014 to &#128;132.4&nbsp;million and the number of seats sold decreased by 7.9% to 691.890.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In 2015, total seats sold decreased by 7.2% to 1,543,259 from 1,662,295 units sold in 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	See &#147;Item 4. Information on the Company&#151;Markets&#148; for tables setting forth the Group&#146;s net leather- and fabric-upholstered
	furniture sales and seats sold, which are broken down by geographic market, for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2013, 2014 and 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The following provides a more detailed country-by-country examination of the changes in volumes in our principal markets, according to the
	Group&#146;s main sales categories:
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	&#149;
<B>
	Natuzzi
</B>
	. In terms of net sales under the Natuzzi brand, the Group recorded positive
	results in USA +22.5% (+1.6% in terms of seats), Italy +10.0% (+7,9% in terms of seats), China +29.8% (+8% in terms of seats), Spain +7,4% (+5.0% in terms of seats), Korea +45.2% (-2.4% in terms of seats), Mexico +26,2% (+5.6% in terms of seats).
	Negative results were achieved in United Kingdom -1.1% (-10.2% in terms of seats), Canada -8.2% (-22.1% in terms of seats), Australia -2,9% (-18.7% in terms of seats), Belgium -3.2% (-7.7% in terms of seats), Germany -26.8% (-14.5% in terms of
	seats), Brazil -0.5% (-10.3% in terms of seats), France -21.0% (-24.6% in terms of seats), Switzerland -11.6% (-18.0% in terms of seats), Israel -3.2% (-7.4% in terms of seats), Japan -4.8% (-24.5% in terms of seats), Taiwan -9.9% (-38.9% in terms
	of seats) and Russia -36.8% (-39.6% in terms of seats).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	&#149;
<B>
	Private Label
</B>
	. In terms of net sales the Group recorded positive
	results in USA +2.7% (-16.4% in terms of seats), United Kingdom +184.5% (+221,4% in terms of seats), Germany +12.9% (+3.1 in terms of seats), Switzerland +21.1% (+27.6% in terms of seats), Korea +&#128;2.4&nbsp;million (compared to &#128;0.0 million
	in 2014), Austria +65,7% (+49.1% in terms of seats) and Israel +37.3% (+25.9% in terms of seats) . Negative results were achieved in France -23.0% (-21.7% in terms of seats), Canada -18.1% (-29.2% in terms of seats), Brazil -25.0% (-40.0% in terms
	of seats) and Japan -21.8% (-35.0% in terms of seats).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Other Net Sales, principally sales of polyurethane foam and leather sold to third
	parties, as well as of accessories and other revenues, decreased slightly by 1,5% to &#128;51.5million, as compared to &#128;52.3&nbsp;million in 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Cost of Sales
</B>
	in 2015 decreased by 0.8% to &#128;330.6&nbsp;million (representing 67.7% of net sales), as compared to
	&#128;333.2&nbsp;million (or 72.2% of net sales) in 2014. In particular, consumption costs (defined as purchases plus beginning stock minus final stock and plus leather processing) decreased as a percentage of total net sales, passing from 47.2% in
	2014 to 46.0% in 2015. This decrease was mainly due to lower leather prices we had in 2015 (approximately 7% price decrease at constant exchange rate compared to 2014), and to the generalized pricelist increase in sofas products. In addition,
	transformation costs were positively affected by the extraordinary corrective measures introduced starting from the second half of 2014 as a means to recover efficiency in our industrial plants (in particular for Italian and Chinese plants). The
	result of such structured action plan was a huge reduction of transformation costs from 25.0% of net sales in 2014 to 21.7% in 2015: a 13.2% improvement achieved only in one year.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Gross Profit
</B>
	. The Group&#146;s gross profit in 2015 amounted to &#128;157.9&nbsp;million (32.3% of net sales), as compared to
	&#128;128.2&nbsp;million in 2014 (27.8% of net sales) as a result of the factors described above.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Selling Expenses
</B>
	increased in
	2015 to &#128;133.4&nbsp;million (27.3% of net sales), as compared to &#128;128.9&nbsp;million in 2014 (27.9% of net sales). In 2015 the Group achieved considerable cost savings for personnel costs, marketing costs, store rent costs and other
	operational expenses that were offset by negative currency transactions and additional provisions for doubtful accounts and warranties.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	43
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage48"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D190845D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	General and Administrative Expenses
</B>
	. In 2015, the Group&#146;s general and administrative
	expenses decreased by &#128;4.2&nbsp;million to &#128;32.1&nbsp;million, from &#128;36.3&nbsp;million in 2014, and, as a percentage of net sales, from 7.9% in 2014 to 6.6% in 2015, due to cost control measures implemented in 2015
<B>
	.
</B>
	In
	particular, remarkable cost savings were achieved for personnel costs (&#128;2.4 million), consultancy costs (&#128; 0.6 million) and travelling expenses (&#128;0.7 million).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Operating Income (Loss).
</B>
	As a result of the factors described above, in 2015 the Group had an operating loss of &#128;7.6&nbsp;million,
	compared to an operating loss of &#128;37.0&nbsp;million in 2014. In 2015, after five years, the Group achieved a positive EBITDA of &#128;6.9&nbsp;million compared to a negative 2014 EBITDA of &#128;22.7.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Other Income (expenses), net
</B>
	. The Group registered &#147;Other expense, net,&#148; of &#128;8.3&nbsp;million in 2015 as compared to
	&#147;Other expense, net,&#148; of &#128;10.6&nbsp;million in 2014. &#147;Other expense, net&#148; of 2015 includes an accrual of &#128;3.4&nbsp;million to the one-termination benefit reserve, while no accruals were recorded in 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Net interest expense, included in other expense, net, in 2015 was &#128;3.3&nbsp;million, as compared to net expenses of
	&#128;1.9&nbsp;million in 2014. The increase of such expense, net was mainly due to additional interest expenses connected with the securitization of trade receivables as well as to minor interest income. See Note 28 to the Consolidated Financial
	Statements included in Item&nbsp;18 of this Annual Report.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Group recorded a &#128;1.1&nbsp;million foreign-exchange net loss in 2015
	(included in other income (expense), net), as compared to a net loss of &#128;2.4&nbsp;million in 2014. The foreign exchange loss in 2015 primarily reflected the following factors:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">

	&nbsp;

	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	a net realized gain of &#128;0.1&nbsp;million in 2015 (as compared to a net realized loss of &#128;0.3&nbsp;million in 2014) on domestic currency swaps due to the difference between the forward rates of the domestic
	currency swaps and the spot rates at which the domestic currency swaps were closed (the Group uses forward rate contracts to hedge its price risks against unfavorable exchange rate variations);
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>

	The Group does not use hedge accounting and records all fair value changes of its domestic currency swaps in its statement of operations. See
	Note 28 to the Consolidated Financial Statements included in Item&nbsp;18 of this Annual Report.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Group recorded expenses of
	&#128;3.9&nbsp;million during 2015 that were recorded under &#147;Other, net,&#148; compared to &#147;Other, net&#148; of -&#128;6.3&nbsp;million reported in 2014. The &#128;3.9&nbsp;million under &#147;Other, net&#148; mainly reflected the
	following factors:

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Income Taxes
</B>
	. In
	2015, the Group had an effective tax rate of 3.6% on its losses before taxes and non-controlling interests, compared to the Group&#146;s effective tax rate of 3.8% reported in 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	For the Group&#146;s Italian companies the effective tax rate (
<I>
	i.e.
</I>
	, the obligation to accrue taxes despite reporting a loss before
	taxes) was, in part, due to the regional tax known as &#147;IRAP&#148; (
<I>
	Imposta Regionale sulle Attivit&agrave; Produttive
</I>
	; see Note 18 to the Consolidated Financial Statements included in Item&nbsp;18 of this Annual Report). This regional
	tax is generally levied on the gross profits determined as the difference between gross revenue (excluding interest and dividend income) and direct production costs (excluding interest expenses and other financial costs). As a consequence, even if
	an Italian company reports a pre-tax loss, it could still be subject to this regional tax. In 2015, some Italian companies within the Group reported losses but had to pay IRAP.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	44
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage49"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D190845D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	As in 2015, because most of the Italian and foreign subsidiaries realized significant pre-tax
	losses and were in a cumulative loss position, management did not consider it reasonably certain that the deferred tax assets of those companies would be realized in the scheduled reversal periods (see Note 18 to the Consolidated Financial
	Statements included in Item&nbsp;18 of this Annual Report).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Net Loss
</B>
	. Reflecting the factors above, the Group reported a net loss
	of &#128;16.5&nbsp;million in 2015, as compared to a net loss of &#128;49.4&nbsp;million in 2014. On a per-Ordinary Share, or per-ADS basis, the Group had net losses of &#128;0.3 in 2015, as compared to net losses of &#128;0.9 in 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	As disclosed in Note 31 to the Consolidated Financial Statements included in Item&nbsp;18 of this Annual Report, established accounting
	principles in Italy vary in certain significant respects from generally accepted accounting principles in the United States. Under U.S. GAAP, the Group would have had net losses of &#128;18.9&nbsp;million and &#128;46.0&nbsp;million in 2015 and
	2014, respectively, compared to net losses of &#128;16.5&nbsp;million and &#128;49.4&nbsp;million in 2015 and 2014, respectively under Italian GAAP.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:24PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
<B>
<A NAME="D190845D20F_HTM_TOC190845_32">
</A>
	2014 Compared to 2013
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Total net sales
</B>
	for 2014, including sales of leather and fabric-upholstered furniture and other sales (principally sales of
	polyurethane foam and leather sold to third parties as well as of accessories), increased 2.7% to &#128;461.4&nbsp;million, as compared to &#128;449.1&nbsp;million in 2013.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Net sales for 2014 of leather and fabric-upholstered furniture increased 1.6% to &#128;409.1&nbsp;million, as compared to
	&#128;402.8&nbsp;million in 2013. The 1.6% increase was due principally to a generalized price-list increase in the second part of the year, a positive sales mix contribution, both more than offsetting a negative currency translation effect and a
	reduction in seats sold (from 1,686,347 in 2013 to 1,662,295 in 2014).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Net sales of Natuzzi branded products (which include sales of the
	Group&#146;s two lines of product:
<I>
	Natuzzi Italia
</I>
	, and
<I>
	Natuzzi Editions
</I>
	) accounted for 70.1% of our total upholstery net sales in 2014 (as compared to 72.7% in 2013); net sales of the private label production accounted for 29.9% of our
	total upholstery net sales in 2014 (as compared to 27.3% in 2013). These trends reflect a shift, year-over-year, toward the lower end of our market segment of products.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Net sales for 2014 of leather-upholstered furniture decreased 2.0% to &#128;374.4&nbsp;million, as compared to &#128;382.2&nbsp;million in
	2013, and net sales for 2014 of fabric-upholstered furniture increased 68.3% to &#128;34.7&nbsp;million, as compared to &#128;20.6&nbsp;million in 2013, reflecting a change in consumer preferences for lower-priced products and those with fabric (as
	opposed to leather) upholstery. We anticipate expanding the range of fabric-upholstered offerings, which were not over the past few years an area of strategic focus, under the Business Plan to reflect these trends.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	According to a geographic breakdown in total upholstery net sales, in the Americas (Brazil included), 2014 net sales increased by 5.2% to
	&#128;171.0&nbsp;million, as compared to &#128;162.5&nbsp;million in 2013, and seats sold increased by 4.1% to 842,263, reflecting in particular the 21.1% increase for our medium-low segment Private label sales, that more than offset the 4.4%
	decrease in the Natuzzi branded products sales for that region.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In EMEA, net sales of upholstered furniture in 2014 decreased by 2.6% to
	&#128;184.8&nbsp;million, as compared to &#128;189.7&nbsp;million in 2013, due to a 2.3% decrease in Natuzzi branded offerings, and a 3.7% decrease in sales of our Private Label offerings. Seats sold in the region in 2014 decreased by 8.3% to
	644,681 units.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In the Asia-Pacific region, net sales of upholstered furniture increased by 5.3% to &#128;53.3&nbsp;million, as compared
	to &#128;50.6&nbsp;million in 2013. Seats sold increased by 1.0% in that region to 175,351. This growth was mainly attributable to the Group&#146;s expansion in the Chinese market, where we opened 36 new
<I>
	Natuzzi Editions
</I>
	stores, 10 new
<I>
	Natuzzi Italia
</I>
	stores and three
<I>
	Natuzzi Re-vive
</I>
	mono-brand stores during 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	45
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage50"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D190845D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	According to a breakdown by brand, net sales for 2014 of the Natuzzi branded furniture decreased
	by 2.0% over 2013 to &#128;287.0&nbsp;million, and the number of seats sold decreased by 8.8% to 911,080. Net sales of private label products in 2014 increased by 11.1% over 2013 to &#128;122.2&nbsp;million and the number of seats sold increased by
	9.4% to 751,215.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In 2014, total seats sold decreased by 1.4% to 1,662,295 from 1,686,347 units sold in 2013.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	See &#147;Item 4. Information on the Company&#151;Markets&#148; for tables setting forth the Group&#146;s net leather- and fabric-upholstered
	furniture sales and seats sold, which are broken down by geographic market, for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2012, 2013 and 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The following provides a more detailed country-by-country examination of the changes in volumes in our principal markets, according to the
	Group&#146;s main sales categories:
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	&#149;
<B>
	Natuzzi
</B>
	. In terms of seats sold under the Natuzzi brand, the Group recorded positive
	results in Italy (+5.8%), China (+30.6%), Spain (+10.2%), Israel (+15.2%), Ireland (+12.3%), United Arab Emirates (+6.2%); Switzerland (+9.4%), Lebanon (+23.3%), Singapore (+54.8%). Negative results were reported in the United States (-5.9%), Canada
	(-14.8%), United Kingdom (-4.7%), Germany (-17.3%), Australia (-15.1%), South Korea (-1.0%), Belgium (-14.2%), Japan (-23.5%), France (-45.4%), Brazil (-11.4%), Russia (-26.3%), Mexico (-30.6%), Taiwan (-6.8%).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	&#149;
<B>
	Private label
</B>
	production. In 2014 the Group reported positive results in the United States (+20.2%), Canada (+29.7%), United
	Kingdom (+47.0%), Brazil (+29.6%), Japan (+174.4%), Italy (+53.1%), Israel (+25.3%), Finland (+24.9%), Russia (+90.1%), Mexico (+141.6%), Romania (+49.7%). Negative results we reported in France (-4.6%), Germany (-29.2%), Switzerland (-43.4%),
	Belgium (-6.0%), China (-27.9%), Austria (-6.1%), Sweden (-32.8%), United Arab Emirates (-3.2%), Spain (-49.5%), The Netherlands (-34.3%).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Other Net Sales
</B>
	, principally sales of polyurethane foam and leather sold to third parties, as well as of accessories and other
	revenues, increased by 13.0% to &#128;52.3&nbsp;million, as compared to &#128;46.3&nbsp;million in 2013. The 13.0% increase was mainly due to revenues from sales of raw materials, VAT incentives in Brazil, and other minor revenues.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Cost of Sales
</B>
	in 2014 increased by 5.0% to &#128;333.2&nbsp;million (representing 72.2% of net sales), as compared to
	&#128;317.3&nbsp;million (or 70.7% of net sales) in 2013. In particular, consumption costs (defined as purchases plus beginning stock minus final stock and plus leather processing) increased as a percentage of total net sales, passing from 46.4% in
	2013 to 47.2% in 2014. This increase was mainly due to higher leather prices we suffered in 2014 (approximately 11% price increase compared to 2013) partially offset by the generalized pricelist increase in sofas products achieved in the second part
	of 2014, and by the positive impact of efficiency measures that have been introduced in 2014, including better management of outsourced materials and components. In addition cost of sales was negatively affected by higher transformation costs
	because of the following events that occurred in 2014:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	radical production changes to our manufacturing process in our Chinese plant resulted in inefficiencies during the first part of 2014. As a consequence, we were obliged to adopt one-off extraordinary measures that were
	necessary in order to meet agreed-upon delivery times and not compromise our customer service;
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	&#149;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	low productivity in our Italian plants, due to the staffing of workers on a rotational basis as required by the 2013 Italian Reorganization Agreement.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Gross Profit
</B>
	. The Group&#146;s gross profit in 2014 amounted to &#128;128.2&nbsp;million (27.8% of net sales), as compared to
	&#128;131.8&nbsp;million in 2013 (29.3% of net sales) as a result of the factors described above.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Selling Expenses
</B>
	increased in
	2014 to &#128;128.9&nbsp;million (27.9% of net sales), as compared to &#128;126.6&nbsp;million in 2013 (28.2% of net sales). The increase was mainly due to higher advertising costs and wages costs partially offset by saving from the closure of 10
	DOS in 2014 (in addition to one store having been closed in September 2013).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	General and Administrative Expenses
</B>
	. In 2014, the
	Group&#146;s general and administrative expenses decreased by &#128;1.2&nbsp;million to &#128;36.3&nbsp;million, from &#128;37.5&nbsp;million in 2013, and, as a percentage of net sales, from 8.4% in 2013 to 7.9% in 2014, due to cost control measures
	implemented in 2014
<B>
	.
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	46
</P>

<B>
	Operating Income (Loss).
</B>
	As a result of the factors described above, in 2014 the Group had
	an operating loss of &#128;37.0&nbsp;million, compared to an operating loss of &#128;32.3&nbsp;million in 2013.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Other Income
	(expenses), net
</B>
	. The Group registered &#147;Other expense, net,&#148; of &#128;10.6&nbsp;million in 2014 as compared to &#147;Other expense, net,&#148; of &#128;31.9&nbsp;million in 2013. The change against 2013 is primarily due to the accrual
	for a one-time termination benefit posted in 2013 of &#128;19.9 million.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Net interest expense, included in other expense, net, in 2014
	was &#128;1.9&nbsp;million, as compared to net expenses of &#128;0.5&nbsp;million in 2013. See Note 28 to the Consolidated Financial Statements included in Item&nbsp;18 of this Annual Report.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Group recorded a &#128;2.4&nbsp;million foreign-exchange net loss in 2014 (included in other income (expense), net), as compared to a net
	loss of &#128;2.9&nbsp;million in 2013. The foreign exchange loss in 2014 primarily reflected the following factors:
</P>

</TD>

	As previously described, the caption included in 2013 the accrual for one-time termination benefit of &#128;19.9 million.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Income Taxes
</B>
	. In 2014, the Group had an effective tax rate of 3.8% on its losses before taxes and non-controlling interests, compared
	to the Group&#146;s effective tax rate of 6.4% reported in 2013.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	For the Group&#146;s Italian companies the effective tax rate
	(
<I>
	i.e.
</I>
	, the obligation to accrue taxes despite reporting a loss before taxes) was, in part, due to the regional tax known as &#147;IRAP&#148; (
<I>
	Imposta Regionale sulle Attivit&agrave; Produttive
</I>
	; see Note 18 to the Consolidated Financial
	Statements included in Item&nbsp;18 of this Annual Report). This regional tax is generally levied on the gross profits determined as the difference between gross revenue (excluding interest and dividend income) and direct production costs (excluding
	labor costs, interest expenses and other financial costs). As a consequence, even if an Italian company reports a pre-tax loss, it could still be subject to this regional tax. In 2014, some Italian companies within the Group reported losses but had
	to pay IRAP.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	As in 2014, because most of the Italian and foreign subsidiaries realized significant pre-tax losses and were in a
	cumulative loss position, management did not consider it reasonably certain that the deferred tax assets of those companies would be realized in the scheduled reversal periods (see Note 18 to the Consolidated Financial Statements included in
	Item&nbsp;18 of this Annual Report).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	47
</P>

<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D190845D20F_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Net Loss
</B>
	. Reflecting the factors above, the Group reported a net loss of
	&#128;49.4&nbsp;million in 2014, as compared to a net loss of &#128;68.6&nbsp;million in 2013. On a per-Ordinary Share, or per-ADS basis, the Group had net losses of &#128;0.9 in 2014, as compared to net losses of &#128;1.25 in 2013.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	As disclosed in Note 31 to the Consolidated Financial Statements included in Item&nbsp;18 of this Annual Report, established accounting
	principles in Italy vary in certain significant respects from generally accepted accounting principles in the United States. Under U.S. GAAP, the Group would have had net losses of &#128;46.0&nbsp;million and &#128;62.0&nbsp;million in 2014 and
	2013, respectively, compared to net losses of &#128;49.4&nbsp;million and &#128;68.6&nbsp;million in 2014 and 2013, respectively under Italian GAAP.
</P>
</EFX_RESULTS_OF_OPERATIONS>
<EFX_LIQUIDITY_CAPITAL>
<A NAME="FIS_LIQUIDITY_CAPITAL"></A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:24PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
<B>
<A NAME="D190845D20F_HTM_TOC190845_33">
</A>
	Liquidity and Capital Resources
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In the ordinary course of business, our principal uses of funds are for the payment of operating expenses, working capital requirements,
	capital expenditures. The Group&#146;s principal source of liquidity has historically been its existing cash and cash equivalents and cash flow from operations, supplemented to the extent needed to meet the Group&#146;s short term cash requirements
	by accessing the Group&#146;s existing lines of credit.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	During 2014, the Group experienced some operating difficulties in the
	implementation of the Group Business Plan. The Business Plan foresees, in its main guidelines, product innovation initiatives, with the introduction of the &#147;moving line&#148; production system in Group plants and subsequent re-engineering of
	existing models, and a sharp decrease in fixed and production costs. See &#147;Item 3. Key Information&#151;Risk Factors&#151;The Group has a recent history of losses; the Group&#146;s future profitability, financial condition and ability to
	maintain adequate levels of liquidity depend to a large extent on its ability to overcome macroeconomic and operational challenges,&#148; &#147;Item 3. Key Information&#151;Risk Factors&#151;The Group&#146;s ability to generate the significant
	amount of cash needed to service our debt obligations and comply with our other financial obligations and our ability to refinance all or a portion of our indebtedness or obtain additional financing depends on multiple factors, many of which may be
	beyond our control&#148;.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In 2015, as a result of corrective measures introduced in the second half of 2014, the Group achieved positive
	results in terms of production efficiency (in particular in the Italian and Chinese plants) and in terms of control and reduction of fixed costs and rationalization of the DOS network. As a consequence EBIT improved from -&#128;37.0&nbsp;million in
	2014 to -&#128;7.6&nbsp;million in 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On the basis of the actions described above, during the second part of 2015, Natuzzi management
	prepared the 2016 budget, which was approved by the Board of Directors on November&nbsp;27, 2015. The budget foresees a further improvement in the Group&#146;s results, reaching positive operating results by the end of 2016. These results will be
	achieved mainly because of the positive contribution resulting from measures to improve efficiency, which were implemented during the last year.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	During 2015 as a consequence of the gradual improvements in different areas experienced in 2015 (such as those generated by corrective
	measures to recover efficiency in our industrial plants, Italian and Chinese plants in particular, the rationalization of DOS and the costs savings realized for personnel costs and other general structure expenses ), the Group was able to obtain new
	credit lines to support its cash needs. In particular, the Company was granted a long-term loan by Euro 5&nbsp;million, and a bank overdraft by Euro 2.5&nbsp;million, while the Romanian subsidiary obtained a bank facility in the amount of Euro
	10&nbsp;million, currently used by Euro 7 million. In addition, the existing short-term credit lines were renewed and a non-recourse trade receivable securitization agreement was signed in July 2015 with a top standing Italian financial institution,
	for the sale of a maximum amount of Euro 35&nbsp;million performing receivables, on a revolving basis. Therefore, management believes that the Group has sufficient source of liquidity to fund working capital needs, capital expenditures and other
	contractual obligations for the next 12 months. See &#147;Item 5. Operating and Financial Review and Prospects.&#148;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	As of
	December&nbsp;31, 2015, the Group had cash and cash equivalents on hand of &#128;52.5&nbsp;million, and lines of credit for cash disbursements totalling &#128;97.2&nbsp;million (&#128;46.9 million as of December&nbsp;31, 2014). Existing credit lines
	of 2015 are as follows: a)
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	48
</P>
